
<leme no="1326">
<page no="1">
A NEW
English Dictionary,
CONTAINING A
COLLECTION
OF 
WORDS 
IN THE
English Language, 
Properly Explain'd and Alphabetically 
Dispos'd.
Design'd for the USE of
Gentlemen, Ladies, Foreigners, and all others who
desire to speak or write ENGLISH in its 
present Purity and Perfection.
By <f type="i">B. N. DEFOE,</f> Gent.

<f type="i">Westminster</f>
Printed for JOHN BRINDLEY, at the King's-Arms, in <f type="i">New Bond&shy;
Street</f>, OLIVE PAYNE, at <f type="i">Horace</f>'s-<f type="i">Head</f>, in <f type="i">Round-Court</f>,
in the <f type="i">Strand</f>, JOHN JOLLIFFE, at the <f type="i">Bible</f>, in St. <f type="i">James</f>'s&shy;
<f type="i">Street</f>, ALEXANDER LYON, under <f type="i">Tom</f>'s Coffee-House in
<f type="i">Russel-Street, Covent-Garden</f>, and CHARLES CORBETT, at
<f type="i">Addison</f>'s-<f type="i">Head</f>, and RICHARD WELLINGTON, at the 
Dolphin and Crow, both without <f type="i">Temple-Bar</f> MDCCXXXV. 
</page>

<page no="2">
PREFACE
<f type="i">THe Design of the following Sheets
is so fully explained by the Title 
Page, that there is but little Occasion for
any other Introduction than what that 
might furnish. A very short Preface
may therefore suffice.

THE Compiler cannot charge himself
with having spared any Pains to render
them correct, and so useful, as might 
justify his Publication of them to the
World.

AND 'tis hoped, it will not be pleaded 
to his Disadvantage, that whilst this
Work answers all the valuable Purposes
</page>

<page no="3">
that ought to be expected from a Per&shy;
formance of this Nature, 'tis so fitted, 
as at Pleasure to be made a Pocket Com&shy;
panion, and for a very small Expence to
become the Source of Amusement or In&shy;
stuction Abroad as well as at Home.</f>

<f type="i">THIS being the Author's first Essay
of this Sort, he commits it to the Can&shy;
dour of those who will condescend to give
it Reception, humbly hoping for the Ap&shy;
probation of the Publick, if upon Perusal
it shall be found that he has endeavoured
to deserve it.</f>
</page>

mast and the Stern.</xpln></wordentry>

stance which unites broken
Bones</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calm(a)">CALM,</form> <xpln lang="en">quiet, still, peace&shy;
able.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calm(n)" lexeme="sea(n)">A CALM at Sea,</form> <xpln lang="en">when there

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calm(v)">To CALM,</form> <xpln lang="en">to appease, to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Calvary(pn)">CALVARY,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mountain out
of the City of <f type="i">Jerusalem</f>, so 
called from the Number of
dead Men's Skulls found there.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Calvinism(n)">CALVINISM,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Doctrine

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Calvinist(n)">CALVINISTS,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Followers

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calumniate(v)">To CALUMNIATE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="calumny(n)">CALUMNY,</form> <xpln lang="en">Slander, De&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cambria(pn)">CAMBRIA,</form> <xpln lang="en"><f type="i">Wales</f>, so called.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cambric(n)">CAMBRICK,</form> <xpln lang="en">a fine Linnen

<f type="i">Flanders</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cambridge(pn)">CAMBRIDGE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a City, and

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="camel(n)">CAMEL,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Beast of Burden,

tries.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carnosity(n)">CARNOSITY,</form> <xpln lang="en">a hard fleshy

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="carol(n)">CAROL,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Song usually sung

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cinnamon(n)">CINNAMON,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Spice; the

in the <f type="i">East-Indies</f></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Cinque Ports(n)">CINQUEPORTS,</form> <xpln lang="en">five Havens
on the East part of <f type="i">England</f>,
<f type="i">Hastings, Dover, Romney, Hithe
and Sandwich</f>, to which <f type="i">Rye</f>
and <f type="i">Winchelsea</f> are since added.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports(n)">Lord Warden of the CINQUE&shy;
PORTS,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Governour of those
Havens, who has the Authority
of an Admiral.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="scion(n)">CION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a young Shoot, Sprig,
or Sucker.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cipher(n)">CIPHER,</form> <xpln lang="en">of no value except
a Figure is placed on the Left&shy;
hand of it, which increases its
Value by Tens, also the first
letters of a Person's Name in&shy;
terwoven together Ciphers al&shy;
so signify odd Characters in
which Letters are written,
that they may not be under&shy;
stood</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="circle(n)">CIRCLE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Compass, or
Ring, &c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="circles of the empire(n)">CIRCLES of the Empire,</form> <xpln lang="en">are
Provinces of <f type="i">Germany</f>, of which
there are ten.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="circuit(n)">CIRCUIT,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Compass, a
Tour, also the Journies of the
Judges twice a Year.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="circular(a)">CIRCULAR,</form> <xpln lang="en">round, in Form

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="circulate(v)">To CIRCULATE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to move

man Body.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="circulation(n)">CIRCULATION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a continu&shy;
al Motion round.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="circumcize(v)">To CIRCUMCISE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to cut

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="cistern(n)">CISTERN,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Vessel of Lead

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="composition(n)">COMPOSITION,</form> <xpln lang="en">in <f type="i">Trade</f>, is

Creditors to pay so much in the
Pound.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compositor(n)">COMPOSITOR,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Printer

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="composure(n)">COMPOSURE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Thing com&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compound(n)">COMPOUND,</form> <xpln lang="en">many Things

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="compound(v)">To COMPOUND,</form> <xpln lang="en">to mix, to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="contribution(n)">CONTRIBUTION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a joint

Tax paid by Frontier Towns,
to prevent being plundered</xpln></wordentry>

<page no="77">

of the chief Articles of the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="current money(n)">CURRANT <f type="i">Money</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">good

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Dunmow(pn)">DONMOW,

there was a Custom, that any
Person who had married a Year
and a Day, upon taking Oath

in that time, was entitled to

and violent
wresting of Money, &c. from
any Man, Interest-Money larger
than the Law allows.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="extortioner(n)">EXTORTIONER,</form> <xpln lang="en">one who
practises Extortion, a griping
Usurer.</xpln></wordentry>

Descent from a certain Family.</xpln></wordentry>

another Country, foreign,
strange.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fillet(n)" lexeme="veal(n)">FILLET <f type="i">of Veal</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">the fleshy
part of the Leg adjoining to the
Loin</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fillet(n)" lexeme="horse(n)">FILLETS <f type="i">of a Horse</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">are the 
foreparts of the Shoulder next
the Breast.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filigrane(n)">FILLIGRANE,
FILLEGREAN,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of 
wrought
Work in Gold or Silver, like

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fillip(n)">FILLIP,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Toss of any thing

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filly(n)">FILLY,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Mare Colt.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="filter(n)">A FILTER,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Charm, an

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fin(n)">A FIN,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Fin of a Fish, a

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fine(a)">FINE,</form> <xpln lang="en">spruce, handsome,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="fine(n)">A FINE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Penalty in Money

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forsooth(ex)">FORSOOTH,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Intersection
of Disdain, or Derision, also a 
Title of Respect and Submission
used by a Servant to a Mistress,
&c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="forswear(v)">To FORSWEAR,</form> <xpln lang="en">to swear
falsly.</xpln></wordentry>

a small Number of Men with&shy;

tional, discreet.</xpln></wordentry>

<page no="191">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knead(v)">To KNEAD,</form> <xpln lang="en">to work Meal

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knick-knack(n)">KNICK KNACKS,</form> <xpln lang="en">Curiosities

real Use.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="knife(n)">KNIFE,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Instrument to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knight(n)">KNIGHT,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Title of Ho&shy;
nour bestowed by the King, on
such as he thinks fit to distinguish
from the common Class of Gen&shy;
tlemen, of which there are se&shy;
veral Orders.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Bachelors Knights(n)" lexeme="batchelors(n)">KNIGHTS <f type="i">Batchelors</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the
lowest but most ancient Order.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knight of the Round Table(n)">KNIGHTS <f type="i">of the Round Ta&shy;
ble</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">made by King <f type="i">Arthur</f>, said
to be the most antient in the
World.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knight Banneret(n)">KNIGHTS <f type="i">Bannerets</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">Knights
made in the Field by cutting off
the Point of their Standard, and
making it a Banner.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knights Baronets(n)">KNIGHTS <f type="i">Baronets</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Or&shy;
der erected by King <f type="i">James</f> I.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knight of the Bath(n)">KNIGHTS <f type="i">of the Bath</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Order of Knights created with&shy;
in the Lists of the <f type="i">Baths</f>, who
bathed themselves, and used se&shy;
veral religious Ceremonies, the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Knight of the Garter(n)">KNIGHTS <f type="i">of the Garter</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">an
Order of Knighthood instituted
by King <f type="i">Edward</f> III They are
also called the Knights of St.
<f type="i">George</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Poor Knights of Windsor(n)"><f type="i">Poor</f> KNIGHTS <f type="i">of Windsor</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Messiah(pn)">MESSIAH,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Name and

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="messuage(n)">MESSUAGE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a dwelling

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metal(n)">METAL,</form> <xpln lang="en">a compact body

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metalline(a)">METALLINE,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metamorphosis(n)">METAMORPHOSIS,</form> <xpln lang="en">a

other.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metaphor(n)">METAPHOR,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Figure in
Rhetorick, by which we put a
strange and remote Word for a
proper one, by reason of its
Resemblance to the Thing spo&shy;
ken of, as <f type="i">smiling Meadows</f>, &c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metaphysics(n)">METAPHYSICKS,</form> <xpln lang="en">that part
of Philosophy which treats of
Forms in general abstracted from
Matter. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meteor(n)">A METEOR,</form> <xpln lang="en">certain imper&shy;
fectly mixed Bodies consisting
of Vapours drawn up into the
middle Region of the Air, and
exhibited indifferent Forms, of
which sort is <f type="i">Ignis Fatuus</f>. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="meter(n)">METER,</form> <xpln lang="en">Measure, or Verses
made by Measure.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="metheglin(n)"><f type="i">METHEGLIN</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">Drink made of
Water, Herbs, Honey, Spice, &c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="method(n)">METHOD,</form> <xpln lang="en">is the placing of
Things in their natural Order,
so as to be easiest understood or
retained. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="methodical(a)">METHODICAL,</form> <xpln lang="en">belonging to,
or agreeable to Order and Method.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="misery(n)">MISERY,</form> <xpln lang="en">Wretchedness, Mis&shy;

and the Regulations of the Ac&shy;
tions of Men.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="moralize(v)">To MORALIZE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to give the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="pilot(n)">PILOT,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Person employ'd

Ship, who stands at the Helm,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="print(v)">To PRINT,</form> <xpln lang="en">to practise the
Art of Printing</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="printing(n)">PRINTING,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Art first
invented by <f type="i">Laurence Coster</f> of
<f type="i">Harlem</f> in <f type="i">Holland</f>, or as others
say by <f type="i">John Guttenbourgh</f> in
<f type="i">Germany</f>, and brought into <f type="i">Eng&shy;
land</f> by <f type="i">Caxton</f> and <f type="i">Turner</f>, who 
were sent by King <f type="i">Henry</f> the
VIth to learn it, one of the first
printed Books, now extant, is
<f type="i">Tully's Offices</f>, printed in the
Year 1465, and kept in the
<f type="i">Bodleian</f> Library at <f type="i">Oxford</f></xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prior(a)">PRIOR,</form> <xpln lang="en">before in Order or
Dignity.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prior(n)">A PRIOR,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Head of a
Priory. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="prioress(n)">A PRIORESS,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Nun next

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reason(n)">REASON,</form> <xpln lang="en">thinking; that
Faculty of the Soul whereby we
judge of Things.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reason(v)">To REASON,</form> <xpln lang="en">to discourse
upon or about a thing, to dispute
or argue.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reasonable(a)">REASONABLE,</form> <xpln lang="en">agreeable to
the Rules of Reason, just,
right, conscionable.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reasoning(n)">REASONING,</form> <xpln lang="en">arguing or
debating upon</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reassemble(v)">To REASSEMBLE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to
summon again, to meet toge&shy;
ther again</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="re-assign(v)">To RE-ASSIGN,</form> <xpln lang="en">to assign
again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="re-assignation(n)">A RE-ASSIGNATION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a
new Assignment</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="re-assume(v)">To RE-ASSUME,</form> <xpln lang="en">to retake
to take upon one's self again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="re-assumption(v)">To RE-ASSUMPTION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a ta&shy;
king again, a re-assuming.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="re-baptize(v)">To RE-BAPTIZE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to bap&shy;
tize again</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Rebecca(pn)">REBECCA,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Woman's
Name.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebel(n)">REBEL,</form> <xpln lang="en">one who openly
rebels against the King or State.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebel(v)">To REBEL,</form> <xpln lang="en">to rise up in
Arms, to revolt against one's
Sovereign</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebellion(n)">REBELLION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a rising or
taking up Arms against the su&shy;
preme Power.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebellious(a)">REBELLIOUS,</form> <xpln lang="en">apt to re&shy;
bel, disobedient.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebound(v)">To REBOUND,</form> <xpln lang="en">to fly back,
to bounce up again as a Ball does.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebuild(v)">To REBUILD,</form> <xpln lang="en">to build up
again.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rebuke(v)">To REBUKE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to reprove or
check.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recall(v)">To RECALL,</form> <xpln lang="en">to call back,
or to call home.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recant(v)">To RECANT,</form> <xpln lang="en">to recall
what one has said or written be&shy;
fore</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recantation(n)">RECANTATION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a re&shy;
voking or unsaying. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recapacitate(v)">To RECAPACITATE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to
put one again in a Capacity of do&shy;
ing any thing. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recapitulate(v)">To RECAPITULATE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to
rehearse briefly, or sum up the
Heads of a former Discourse</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recede(v)">To RECEDE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to go back, to
return, to depart from.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receipt(n)">RECEIPT,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Act of Re&shy;
ceiving, an Acquittance for Mo&shy;
ney receiv'd; a Prescription for
Medicine</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receivable(a)">RECEIVABLE,</form> <xpln lang="en">that may be
received</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receive(v)">To RECEIVE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to take what
is given, paid, or put into one's
Hands, also to <f type="i">entertain</f> or
harbor; to admit or allow of,
also to bear or suffer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receiver(n)">RECEIVER,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Person who
receives, also the Name of a
Chymical Vessel.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recent(a)">RECENT,</form> <xpln lang="en">a new, fresh,
lately done or happened.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="receptible(a)">RECEPTIBLE,</form> <xpln lang="en">that may be
received</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recepticle(n)">RECEPTICLE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Place to
receive or keep things in, a Ware&shy;
house or Storehouse, also a Neth&shy;
or lurking Hole.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reception(n)">RECEPTION,</form> <xpln lang="en">receiving any
thing or entertaining a Person</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recess(n)">RECESS</form> <xpln lang="en">a retreating or with
drawing, a Place of Retreat or
Retirement.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="rechase(v)">To RECHASE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to drive back
to the Place where the Game
was first started</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reciprocal(a)">RECIPROCAL,</form> <xpln lang="en">mutual, in&shy;
terchangeable, that is returned on
both sides. </xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="reciprocate(v)">To RECIPROCATE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to re&shy;
quite, to be even with</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recital(n)">A RECITAL,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Act of
reciting, or making a Report, a
Rehearsal, a Saying without 
Book.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="recite(v)">To RECITE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to relate or re&shy;

not stir out of the Religious

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="refit(v)">To REFIT,</form> <xpln lang="en">to fit a Thing

ther Service.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sequestration(n)">SEQUESTRATION,</form> <xpln lang="en">the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheet(n)">SHEET,</form> <xpln lang="en">a large Linnen
Cloth to lay upon a Bed.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shekel(n)">SHEKEL,</form> <xpln lang="en">a <f type="i">Jewish</f> Silver
Coin worth about half a Crown,
and another about half that
Value; also a Gold Coin in
Value about one Pound sixteen
Shillings and six Pence.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shelf(n)">SHELF,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Board made fast

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shell(n)">SHELL,</form> <xpln lang="en">the woody Husk or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shell(v)">To SHELL,</form> <xpln lang="en">to take off the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shelter(n)">SHELTER,</form> <xpln lang="en">a safe Place

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shelter(n)">To SHELTER <f type="i">one</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">to receive

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shelving(n)">SHELVING,</form> <xpln lang="en">slanting.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="shepherd(n)">SHEPHERD,</form> <xpln lang="en">one who

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Sheepy(pn)">SHEEPY,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Isle in the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sherbet(n)">SHERBET,</form> <xpln lang="en">a pleasant Li&shy;

<f type="i">Turks</f>; also a Mixture of Water,

<f type="i">London</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sheriff(n)">A SHERIFF,</form> <xpln lang="en">a chief Officer

narvonshire</f>, which has always

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snub(v)">To SNUB,</form> <xpln lang="en">to sob; also to
take one up smartly, to keep

of Business.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="snuffling(a)" lexeme="fellow(n)" lexeme="snivelling(a)">A SNUFFLING <f type="i">Fellow</f>,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="sound(n)">The SOUND,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Streight of

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stand(n)">A STAND,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Pause or Stay,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stock(v)">To STOCK,</form> <xpln lang="en">to supply, to fur&shy;
nish.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stock(n)">STOCKS,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Engine for the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="stone(n)" lexeme="wool(n)">STONE <f type="i">of Wool</f></form> <xpln lang="en">fourteen

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="term(n)">TERM,</form> <xpln lang="en"><f type="i">(in Law)</f> a fixed and

Suits; there are four in a Year,
<f type="i">Hilary, Easter, Trinity</f>, and <f type="i">Mi&shy;
chaelmas</f> Term.</xpln></wordentry>

Troubles</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="travested(a)" lexeme="travesty(n)">TRAVESTED,

</page>

<page no="358">
prince, whether by Imagination,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verity(n)">VERITY,</form> <xpln lang="en">Truth.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verjuice(n)">VERJUICE,</form> <xpln lang="en">the Juice of
sour unripe Grapes, Crabs, &c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vermilion(n)">VERMILION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a lively deep
red Colour.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vermin(n)">VERMIN,</form> <xpln lang="en">any kind of
hurtful Creatures or Insects, as
Rats, Mice, Lice, Fleas, Buggs,
&c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verminous(a)">VERMINOUS,</form> <xpln lang="en">full of
Worms, worm-eaten</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vernal(a)">VERNAL,</form> <xpln lang="en">of or belonging to
the Spring.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verrel(n)">VERREL,
VERRIL,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Terrel, a little 
Brass or Iron
Ring at the end of a Cane, or
Handle of a Tool.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verse(n)">VERSE,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Order of Words
having a certain Cadence, and
measured by a determinate Num&shy;
ber of Feet, which in the Mo&shy;
dern Languages for the most part
end in Rhime; also a small
Portion of a Chapter in the Bible.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="versification(n)">VERSIFICATION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a mak&shy;
ing of Verses, or the Art of
making Verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="versifier(n)">VERSIFIER,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Maker of
Verses, a Poet, but the Word is
generally taken for a paltry Rhy&shy;
mer.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="versify(v)">To VERSIFY,</form> <xpln lang="en">to make
Verses.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="version(n)">VERSION,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Translation out
of one Language into another.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vertex(n)">VERTEX,</form> <xpln lang="en">the top of any
thing.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vertically(adv)">VERTICALLY,</form> <xpln lang="en">at the
point.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vertigo(n)">VERTIGO,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Giddiness,
Dizziness or swimming in the
Head.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="virtue(n)">VERTUE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Disposition of
the Soul by which a Man is in&shy;
clined to good, and shun Evil,
moral Honesty, good Principles.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vertuoso(n)">VERTUOSO,</form> <xpln lang="en">an accom&shy;
</page>

<page no="367">
plished and ingenious Person, one
well versed in Philosophy</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="virtuous(a)">VERTUOUS,</form> <xpln lang="en">inclined or dis&shy;
posed to Vertue. See <f type="i">Virtuous</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Verulam(pn)">VERULAM,</form> <xpln lang="en">a famous City

mans</f>, out of whole Ruins St. <f type="i">Al&shy;
bans</f> was raised.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="verily(adv)">VERILY,</form> <xpln lang="en">truly, indeed, in

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vesicatory(n)">A VESICATORY,</form> <xpln lang="en">any Me&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vesper(n)">VESPERS,</form> <xpln lang="en">Evening Prayers in

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vessel(n)">A VESSEL,</form> <xpln lang="en">a general Name

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vessel(n)" lexeme="paper(n)">VESSEL <f type="i">of Paper</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">half a quar&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vest(v)">To VEST,</form> <xpln lang="en">to bestow upon, to

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vest(n)">VEST,</form> <xpln lang="en">a sort of Wastecoat or

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestment(n)">VESTMENT,</form> <xpln lang="en">Raiment,

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestry(n)">VESTRY,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Room adjoining

Vestments and sacred Utensils are
kept, an Assembly of the Heads
of the Parish usually held in that
Place.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestry-clerk(n)">VESTRY-<f type="i">Clerk</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Officer

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vestryman(n)">VESTRY-<f type="i">Men</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a select Num&shy;
ber of the principal Inhabitants,
who usually chuse Officers for the

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vesture(n)">VESTURE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Garment, any

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vice(n)">A VICE,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Instrument used

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vice(n)">VICE,</form> <xpln lang="en">in composition of <f type="i">Eng&shy;
lish</f> words, implies the supplying

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vice-admiral(n)">VICE-<f type="i">Admiral</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the

vy, who commands the Second
Squadron, and has his Flag set up
at the Fore-Top of the Ship.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="vice-chamberlain(n)">VICE-<f type="i">Chamberlain</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">a great Of&shy;
ficer at Court next to the Lord
Chamberlain, who, in his absence
has the command of all Officers
belonging to that part of the King's
Houshold, which is called the
Chamber or above Stairs.</xpln></wordentry>

from <f type="i">London</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wary(a)">WARY,</form> <xpln lang="en">cautious, provident,
wise.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wassail(n)">WASSAIL,
WASSEL,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Custom still 
used in some
Places on <f type="i">twelfth Day</f> at Night of
going about with a great Bowl of
Ale, drinking to Peoples Healths.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="wassailer(n)">WASSELLERS,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Company
of People who make merry and
drink together; also Wenches that
go about from House to House
singing at <f type="i">Christmas</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waste(v)">To WASTE,</form> <xpln lang="en">to spoil, to
make havock.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waste(n)">WASTE,</form> <xpln lang="en">spoil, havock, de&shy;

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waste ground(n)">WASTE <f type="i">Ground</f>,</form> <xpln lang="en">those Lands
which are not in any Man's Posses&shy;
sion, but lie in Common.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="waist(n)">WASTE,</form> <xpln lang="en">the middle of a

of Fish, and the gathering of the
Toll that arises from the River of
<f type="i">Thames</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="year(n)">YEAR,</form> <xpln lang="en">the time the Sun takes
up in going through the 12 Signs
of the <f type="i">Zodiack</f>, and the Year is
also <f type="i">Solar</f> or <f type="i">Lunar</f>. The <f type="i">Solar</f>
Year is that time the Sun takes
up to go from one point of
the <f type="i">Ecliptick</f> to the same again,
and contains 365 Days, 5 Hours,
and 12 Minutes; the <f type="i">Lunar</f> con&shy;
tains 12 <f type="i">Lunations</f> and is less
than the <f type="i">Solar</f> by 11 Days, the
exact Duration being 354 Days,
8 Hours and 48 Minutes.</xpln></wordentry>

</page>

<page no="390">
<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zinziber(n)">ZINZIBER,</form> <xpln lang="en">Ginger, a sort 
of Spice.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zodiac(n)">ZODIACK,</form> <xpln lang="en">one of the grea&shy;
test Circles in the Heavens about
which the Sun goes once every
Year, and the Moon once a Month.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zoilus(pn)">ZOILUS,</form> <xpln lang="en">an envious Person.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zone(n)">ZONE,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Belt or Girdle.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zoography(n)">ZOOGRAPHY,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Description
of the Nature and Property of any
kind of Animals, as Birds, Beasts,
Fishes, Serpents, Insects, &c.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zoographer(n)">ZOOGRAPHER,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Describer
or Painter of Living Creatures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zoology(n)">ZOOLOGY,</form> <xpln lang="en">a Treatise concern&shy;
ing Living Creatures.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zootomy(n)">ZOOTOMY,</form> <xpln lang="en">an Artificial Dis&shy;
section of the Bodies of brute Beasts
or any other Creatures except
Men</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="Zoroaster(pn)" lexeme="first(a)" lexeme="inventor(n)" lexeme="magic(n)">ZOROASTER the first In&shy;
ventor of Magick,</form> <xpln lang="en">whom <f type="i">Pliny</f>
takes to be much more ancient
than <f type="i">Moses</f>.</xpln></wordentry>

<wordentry type="h"><form lang="en" lexeme="zuz(n)">ZUZ,</form> <xpln lang="en">a <f type="i">Hebrew</f> Coin in value
Seven-pence Half-penny <f type="i">English</f>.</xpln></wordentry>
</wordgroup1>

<f type="i">FINIS.</f>
